answers.answer: Well from what I gather there isnt much you can do about it.  the statistics say that 8 in 100 women have this problem. What has the doctor suggested to you?  You need to talk to your doctor asap to make sure he gives you the answers you are looking for.this is all i could find in regards to what you are askingWhat You Can DoThe best thing you can do is to go to all your prenatal care appointments. Your health care provider can monitor the size of your belly and how much amniotic fluid is in your womb. If you have a problem, your provider can take steps to help prevent complications in you and your baby.Women with high blood pressure, diabetes, lupus and placental problems are at increased risk for oligohydramnios. If you have any of these conditions, be sure to let your health care provider know.If you have high blood pressure:• Talk to your health care provider before pregnancy (or as soon as you think you are pregnant).• Be sure any medications you are taking are safe during pregnancy• Be sure your blood pressure is well controlled.If you have oligohydramnios, be sure to eat a healthy and nutritious diet, drink lots of fluids (water is best), get plenty of rest, avoid smoking, and report any signs of preterm labor to your health care provider right away.
